awd_titl_txt: Between the Disk and the Star: Boundary Layers in Astrophysical Accretion Disks
awd_abstract_narration:
This study will explore a tantalizing new mechanism for explaining activity within the region between an inward flow of material and the central object onto which it is falling.  Detailed numerical work including for the first time all of the relevant physical ingredients will predict what should be observed.  The project promises finally to make progress after a long time spent on ideas that simply did not work, and it will train students in this cutting-edge research topic.

Astrophysical accretion often proceeds onto a central object with a surface, in which case a boundary layer forms at the inner edge of the disk.  Energy release in this layer dramatically affects the spectra and variability of accreting objects, which requires a good working model of the boundary.  This project starts with a recently discovered important new mechanism for angular momentum and mass transport across this region.  The transport mechanism comes from supersonic shear flows that give rise to global acoustic waves that dissipate in weak shocks.  It appears to be very efficient and robust, and needs to be further studied.  This work will identify and explore the properties of acoustic modes in fully three-dimensional, magneto-hydrodynamic (MHD) boundary layers, in which the effects of radiation transfer and/or radiation pressure are important.  The study involves detailed simulations using a three-dimensional (3D) MHD code and careful analysis of the results, trying to find simple physically motivated models of transport driven by acoustic modes.  The culmination of the work is a set of simulations combining these previously explored physical ingredients.  This parameter space exploration to understand the global geometry and characteristics of the boundary layer has never been done before, and will lead to direct prediction of observable quantities.  These calculations will be the first self-consistent model of the structure and evolution of boundary layers not relying on ad-hoc angular momentum transport prescriptions.

The project will make special efforts to recruit students from minority and underrepresented groups, training personnel highly qualified for future success.  The simulations will result in visualizations appropriate for the general public, for public talks and general outreach purposes.

por.por_cntn:
The main focus of this project was to provide a better understanding of the physics of accretion onto a variety of astrophysical objects possessing a material surface. Such objects include weakly magnetized neutron stars in X-ray binaries, white dwarfs in cataclysmic variables, FU Orioni objects (young stars accreting gas from their protoplanetary disks at high rates), young planets, and so on. A common feature of these objects is that the gas orbiting with high velocity near their surfaces must be slowed down somehow in the so-called boundary layer for the material in the disk to be accreted onto the central object. How this happens has been a mystery for many decades largely because of the lack of understanding of the angular momentum transport in the boundary layers. 

Situation changed several years ago when a robust new transport mechanism was identified in global simulations of the boundary layers: excitation of the sonic instability, which generates large scale density waves in the disk and inside the star, carrying angular momentum and energy. This global transport process is very different in nature from the local stress that is expected to be produced by the magneto-rotational instability. Thus, it is imperative to understand the inner workings of this novel physical phenomenon, which is the main motivation behind this project.

As a part of our study, we ran a suite of large-scale numerical simulations to explore the physics of the inner regions of accretion disks adjacent to the stellar surface, focusing on the boundary layer region. This allowed us to explore the characteristics of the acoustic modes serving as the primary means of the angular momentum and energy transport in the disk. We have also made a discovery of a new type of modes in the near-boundary layer region ? the so-called vortex-driven modes (see Figure 1), which are generated by a system of large-scale vortices spontaneously appearing in the disk near the stellar surface. We provided extensive analysis and understanding of the different types of wave-like structures, and fully characterized their transport properties.

Another major result of this study is the discovery of time variability of accretion disk emission, which is caused by the wave-like processes taking place in the boundary layer region. By simulating the light curves of such objects, we were able to show that operation of different modes generated in the boundary layer endows the light output of these objects with characteristic periodicity, seen both by eye (see Figure 2) as well as in Fourier domain (see Figure 3). The characteristic frequency of this quasi-periodicity is very reminiscent of that observed in some accreting objects, in particular, accreting white dwarfs in cataclysmic variable systems.

A number of ancillary results have been obtained during this project, both analytical and numerical, in particular relevant for understanding propagation and dissipation of modes in the disk. It has also been shown that the acoustic mode-mediated transport can be highly relevant for understanding the so-called spreading layers, which may form if the accreted matter can freely spread over the surface of the accretor.

These results greatly enrich our understanding of the physics of accretion phenomena across the Universe. Experience gained as part of carrying out this project is being utilized in building the next-generation three-dimensional models of the boundary layers, which will fully include magnetohydrodynamic effects and improved thermal physics.
